questions.text:

The student uses the equipment shown in Fig. 1.1.
Table 1.1 shows the results obtained.

parts.text: Describe how to determine the volume of an irregular object with the measuring cylinder.
parts.answer: reading / volume with water / liquid alone or use displacement can filled (to spout) && subtracted from reading (of volume) with object (submerged) in cylinder or place rock in displacement can and measure volume of overflow with measuring cylinder

parts.text: Calculate the density of iron.
parts.answer: (d =) M / V algebraic or numerical  &&  7.8 g / cm3

parts.text:
A third object, which is also made of copper, has the same volume as the iron object.
Calculate the mass of this copper object.
parts.answer: 350 x 51 / 39 or (density of Cu =) 350 / 39 or or 9.0 (g / cm3) seen  &&  460 g

parts.text: State and explain what happens to the density of the iron object when it is heated.
parts.answer: (density) decreases && and volume increases / object expands or molecular explanation of expansion

questions.text:
Fig. 2.1 shows a container of gas connected to a manometer. The tube in the manometer has a
constant cross-sectional area.
The gas in the container exerts a pressure.

parts.text: Define the term pressure.
parts.answer: force per unit area

parts.text:
The density of mercury is 1.4 x 10^4 kg/m^3. The gravitational field strength g is 10 N/kg.

parts.answer: (P=) dgh algebraic or numerical  &&  0.16 x 1.4 x 10^4 x 10 or 22 400 (Pa) seen  &&  7.8 x 10^4 Pa

parts.text:
In Fig. 2.1, the mercury level on the left-hand side of the manometer is lower than on the right-hand side.
The gas inside the container is heated. This causes the mercury levels on both sides to become the same.
Determine the mercury level, as shown on the ruler, when this happens.
Explain, in terms of the gas molecules, what causes the level of mercury to become the same.
parts.answer: (molecules) move faster / have more kinetic energy && (molecules) hit sides / walls / mercury / container && (molecules) hit harder or more often / more frequently / more violently / vigorously or (molecules) create large(r) pressure / large(r) force or eventually (molecules) exert same pressure as air

parts.text: On Fig. 3.1, mark the critical angle and label it c.

parts.text: State why only one of the three rays is totally internally reflected.
parts.answer: angle of incidence (of right-hand ray only) greater than the critical angle

parts.text:
Calculate:
the refractive index for water
parts.answer: (n=) sin i / sinr algebraic or numerical  &&  1.3

parts.text:

the critical angle for the boundary between water and air.

questions.text:
A star emits electromagnetic radiation over a range of wavelengths.
Fig. 4.1 shows the brightness of the radiation from the star at different wavelengths.
Radiation from the star is brightest at one wavelength.

parts.text: Determine the wavelength where the radiation is brightest.

Visible light has a wavelength between 4.0 x 10^-7 m and 7.0 x 10^-7 m
The radiation in (a) lies just outside the visible part of the electromagnetic spectrum.
State the name of the region of the spectrum that contains the radiation in (a).
parts.answer: infra-red

parts.text:
Determine the frequency of the radiation in (a).
The speed of light is 3.0 x 10^8 m/s.
parts.answer: (f = v / λ) algebraic or numerical  &&  3 x 108 / 1.2 x 10^-6  &&  2.5 x 10^14 Hz

parts.text:
Fig. 5.1 shows part of a machine used to investigate electrostatic charging.
Before the machine is switched on the metal dome and the ball are uncharged.
When the machine is switched on, the metal dome becomes negatively charged.
Explain how charging the dome causes the metal ball P to become positively charged.
parts.answer: negative charge / electrons / experience repulsive force (from dome) && negative charge / electrons are earthed / move to earth

parts.text:
A photocopier works using electrostatic charging. It contains a drum whose surface conducts charge where it is exposed to light.
Fig. 5.2 shows a piece of paper, the drum and the heater of a photocopier.
The photocopier produces a copy of an original page on a piece of paper.
The sentences below describe the process of making the copy but the sentences are in the wrong order.
A The drum is given a positive charge.
B The positively charged parts of the drum attract a black powder.
C Where light hits the drum, the positive charge leaks away.
D An image of the original page is projected onto the drum.
E The drum rolls against a piece of paper, transferring powder to the paper.
F The paper is heated which makes the black powder stick to it.
Arrange the sentences in the correct order.
parts.answer: D at start or E at end && D C B E A

questions.text:

questions.text:

parts.answer: (distance) has no direction or (distance) is a scalar

parts.answer: changes direction or goes round a corner && velocity changes or velocity depends on direction or acceleration / force is towards the centre of circle / centripetal

parts.text:

parts.answer: distance travelled before brakes applied (after seeing emergency)

parts.text:

parts.answer: any 2 of , poor tyre surface , poor road conditions, e.g. rain, ice , high speed (of car) or good aerodynamic car shape or tail wind , large mass / weight of car , driver applies less force to pedal / less braking force

parts.text: Explain why the temperature of the brakes increases during braking.

questions.text:
Fig. 10.1 is a diagram of a soldering iron.
Solder is a mixture of metals used to make a permanent contact between electrical wires.

parts.answer: metal tip 1000 °C && solder 200 °C

parts.answer: (E= )VIt algebraic or numerical  &&  790 J

parts.answer: ANY TWO from , can measure rapid temperature changes , can measure high temperatures , is small in size , has a small heat capacity , can give electrical signal / be read by computer

parts.text:

parts.text:

parts.answer: Any 2 from: high pressure , (very) high temperature , high particle density

2α
